captions.text:
Chris: Welcome to the cupola, 
ready to play a little music!

Ed: Indeed! Your scenery looks 
a little nicer than ours!
Have you got everything you need?

Do you have your trusty 
floating guitar pick with you?

Excellent. 
Mine is subject to gravity.

Yeah, I know, 
yours matches your mission patch.

Gleeks, 
are you guys ready to do this?
Gleeks: Yeah!!
Ed: Chris? Ready to go?
Chris: Yes Ed, I'm ready.
Ed: Okay!
Chris: Let's do this!
Ed: Let's do it.
♫ folk-pop music ♫

Ed (singing): 
On solid fuel and wires

Turn the key 
and the light the fires.
We’re leaving Earth today
This rocket's burning bright,
We’ll soon be out of sight,
And orbiting in space.

Ed and Chris: 
Pushed back in my seat,
Look out my window.
There goes home.
That ball of shiny blue

houses everybody 
anybody ever knew.

All together: 
So sing your song, I’m listening
Out where stars are glistening

I can hear your voices 
bouncing off the moon
If you could see our nation

from the 
International Space Station

You’d know why 
I want to get back soon.
Gleeks: Get back soon...

Chris: 
Eighteen thousand miles an hour
Fueled by science and solar power
The oceans racing past...
At half a thousand tons
Ninety minutes moon to sun
A bullet can’t go half this fast

Ed and Chris: 
Floating from my seat
Look out my window
There goes home

Gleeks: 
There goes home...

Ed and Chris: 
That brilliant ball of blue

All together: Is where I’m from, 
and also where I’m going to...
So sing your song, I’m listening
Out where stars are glistening

I can hear your voices 
bouncing  off the moon
If you could see our Nation

from the 
International Space Station

Chris: You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
Gleeks: Get back soon...

Ed: All back and white 
just fades to grey

Where the sun rises 
sixteen times a day

Chris: You can’t make out borders 
from up here

Just a spinning ball 
within a tiny atmosphere
Gleeks: Atmosphere...

Ed and Chris: 
Pushed back in my seat
Look out my window
Here comes home
Gleeks: Ho-oooh-home....

Ed and Chris: 
What once  was fueled by fear

All together: Now has fifteen nations 
orbiting together here.
So sing your song, I’m listening
Out where stars are glistening

I can hear your voices 
bouncing off the moon
If you could see our nation

from the 
International Space Station

You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
Gleeks: Get back soon...

Ed: You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
Gleeks: Getting back to you

Chris: You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
Gleeks: Getting back to you

Ed: You’d know why 
I want to get back soon
Gleeks: Getting back to you

Chris: You’d know why 
I want to get back soon

comments.author: Ashley DaRosa

comments.text:
Good song, horrible lyrics. It feels the song is trying to have a kind of 
'Imagine' feel with Chris Hadfield's mention of not being able to see 
borders from space, and the whole International aspect, but this is ruined 
by the chorus line, "If you could see 'our nation' from the 'international' 
space station, you'd know why i want to get back soon." Throwing a massive 
spanner in the works with a reference to one nation being better than the 
combined efforts of all. No matter how beautiful space is, and the prospect 
of nations putting differences aside, there's nothing better than good ol' 
nationalism!﻿

comments.text:
this astronaut is very inspirational, and so is his music. I like how he 
carefully made sure to mention. When you Look Back at the earth. their are 
no borders. I am sure many Astronauts have processed the thoughts of how 
Foolish Man is to think we Can own the Land Individually Or Our 
Governments. As we Soon begin to run Low on Vital Resources. Here is to 
hope against all hope. Borders will grow out of Favor with the Logic of 
Common sense. Not Some Of. All of us need to remember Bob MarLeys sacred 
Verse's One World, One Love. what are we gonna do when Global warming gives 
rise to the Sea, and Millions upon Millions are displaced. We should forget 
Borders for the sake of humanity. Chief Joseph, and John Lennon Had some 
enlightened views on the subject as well. I can understand for purpose of 
property tax's. yet when we die we can not take it with us. in the sense of 
time, and memorial we can not truly own Land. We are simply stewards of it.
 If Only People in high places of our governments thought of themselves as 
humble Stewards think how much better things would be.=)﻿

comments.author: Nada Bishir

comments.text:
What does latency have to do with it, if you are playing in sync with the
latency? So if someone in space started with a click track or count down,
and you didn't get the countdown for several seconds, you would still be
playing at the same time as the music reached you, so you record it in real
time that way, only the one in space would not be able to hear you or it
would mess them up so they would be playing alone in their ears. They could
later listen to the collaboration after it was mixed though.﻿

comments.text:
I saw Chris tonight in St John's and wanted to say that his talk tonight 
was amazing.  The big thing I wanted to say specific to this was that He 
played the first part of this song and people (including myself) were 
singing along with him.  He  (Ed also) have touched so many people in 
Canada you are a national hero, It seems like another world wide solidarity 
song...especially after his talk about seeing borders disappear..(new 
verse)..  You guys did something amazing and when I saw Chris with tears 
tonight after and then giving his guitar pick to the girl in the front row 
a couple next to me broke down.....Chris is an amazing ambassador and Ed 
you are too.  Keep fighting the long goal about maintaining out planet for 
our future generations.

Love you both.

 ﻿

comments.text:
I may be wrong, but the ISS is between 330 and 435 km above us, so that's

comments.author: tralalalalallala

comments.text:
The difference is between an ISP and a Space Agency.
Only part of what Marcel has said is right. What a lot of people don't 
realise at the moment is the Canadian Government have actually surpassed 
most of the world in inter/tele/stellar comms (ITSC). Physics only can get 
you so far, but Canadians can get you even further.
comments.author: Chris Snopek

comments.text:
truethera, you sound like you do lots of reading but have no practical 
experience. I manage a number of sites on low earth orbit delivered 
service. tracert clearly points out a 650ms latency spike. I may have over 
estimated the difference to the ISS. In the case of satellite delivered 
connections, its 650-750ms. You seem like a smart guy, I hope you get some 
experience with computers someday so you don't sound like an idiot.
comments.author: Marcel Broesky

comments.text:
+Marcel Broesky Lies. Physics. Speed of light and speed of electromagnetic 
waves (radio and alike). Thats how signal goes. And the low orbit  (aka 
under 200 miles) is less then 10 ms on the both handshake and return data 
transfer. You sound like you mean it, but its only your incompetent dreams.
comments.author: truethera

comments.text:
He would experience at least 1500ms ping. A low earth orbit communications 
satellite is somewhere around 750ms. I would estimate no less than double 
the latency given the increased distance. Its possible there is more. It 
wouldn't be possible to play at the same time.
comments.author: Marcel Broesky

comments.text:
+Sudhish Raghupatruni Hadfield's part was pre recorded in space then sent 
to earth
comments.author: Wayne Choi (AsuranZala)

comments.text:
+LemmingAttack I may be wrong, but I'm under the impression that Chris' 
part was actually recorded in a studio and not in space.
comments.author: Sudhish Raghupatruni

comments.text:
+George Hopkins If you pay closer attention, you can tell it wasn't a 2-way 
conversation. Hadfield didn't respond to the guitar pick question, he 
simply held it up, and he started bringing it up before he was even asked, 
and it's not hard to collaborate ahead of time and practice timing to make 
it look like you're having a conversation with a recording.

comments.author: Sch Mam

comments.text:
*An Anthem for All Nations*
*"Look out my window, there goes home. That ball of shiny blue  - houses 
everybody anybody ever knew."*  In the song, *"I.S.S. - Is Somebody 
Singing"*, sung by Canadian Astronaut, Chris Hadfield (from the 
International Space Station), The Barenaked Ladies and the Wexford Gleeks, 
the wonder and perspective of looking back on our planet Earth is shared 
with us all. The planet Earth, seen from space, has no borders.  This song 
will give you shivers.﻿
comments.author: Marilyn van Millingen

comments.text:
Ahh, thanks for the correction, because I experience both MF and ASMR.
Whether I could call them both ASMR is because I can get those shivers at 
will or unexpectedly from things like music (other stimuli)
comments.author: dah4x

comments.text:
An interesting comment +dah4x . I looked it up and believe what I mentioned 
is closer to what is called, "musical frisson", which is described as 
feeling like shivering and definitely comes from hearing certain passages 
of music, not from other stimuli. +Oscar Enciso
comments.author: Marilyn van Millingen

comments.text:
+Oscar Enciso It isn't actually shivering, despite coming from the same 
part of the brain.
Its known as Autonomous sensory meridian response.
comments.author: dah4x

comments.text:
Thank-you, +Oscar Enciso , for your comment. I loved the melody and the 
philosophy of the song. When the choir started singing, it was, 'the icing 
on the cake'. Hi There!/Salut! from Ottawa, Canada!
comments.author: Marilyn van Millingen

comments.text:
SPOT ON MARILYN! IT DID GIVE ME THE SHIVERS!! THANK YOU FOR SHARING IT!! 
AND BRAVO! TO THE HADFIELD BROTHERS!!
I LOVE CANADIANS! VERY UNIQUE PEOPLE!! LOVE TO SEE THEIR COUNTRY TOO! from 
Melbourne, Australia. "G'DAY" to you all!!
comments.author: Oscar Enciso
